item.title: China Exempts Major EU Brandy Makers From Anti-Dumping Duty
item.description: China imposed anti-dumping duties on European brandy for five years, while exempting major cognac makers that committed to keeping their prices above minimum levels.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Lulu Shen, Hallie Gu

media:content.media:description: Remy Martin Photographer: Bryan Bedder/Getty Images

item.title: France’s Industry Minister Says 10% Tariffs Not Good Deal for EU
item.description: French Industry Minister Marc Ferracci said agreeing to 10% tariffs on European exports to the US would be a bad deal, signaling disapproval of a potential compromise with Washington.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin, Caroline Connan, Francois De Beaupuy

media:content.media:description: Marc Ferracci at the Les Rencontres Economiques economic conference in Aix-en-Provence, on July 4.

item.title: ECB Risks 2% Undershoot If Euro Strength Persists, Villeroy Says
item.description: The European Central Bank is at greater risk of undershooting its inflation target following a sharp appreciation of the exchange rate, Governing Council member Francois Villeroy de Galhau said.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin, Caroline Connan, Jana Randow

item.title: BOE’s ‘Old Lady’ Building to Get Biggest Makeover in 80 Years
item.description: The Bank of England’s historic London office is preparing for its biggest make-over since World War II.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: The Bank of England’s main building in the City of London.

item.title: Japanese Price Expert Says Inflation Outpacing BOJ’s View
item.description: Japan’s inflation is surprisingly strong, increasing the possibility that the Bank of Japan will raise its interest rate by the end of the year, according to one of the country’s leading inflation experts.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka, Sumio Ito

media:content.media:description: Tsutomu Watanabe Source: Tsutomu Watanabe

item.title: ECB Warns of Impact of Heat Waves on Inflation, GDP Growth
item.description: The link between heat and key economic indicators such as inflation and gross domestic product is too important to ignore, according to European Central Bank Executive Board member Frank Elderson.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber, Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of the European Central Bank in Frankfurt. Photographer: Ben Kilb/Bloomberg

item.title: Nassim Taleb on Living a Good Life in an Age of Volatility
item.description: Staying prepared for Black Swans.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: Nassim Nicholas Taleb speaking on stage during an live taping of the Odd Lots podcast in New York City, on Thursday, June 26, 2025.

item.title: Quickening Inflation Adds to Czech Central Bank’s Cautious Case
item.description: Czech inflation accelerated in June to the fastest pace this year, supporting policymakers’ cautious approach and limiting room for further interest-rate cuts.
item.dc:creator: Peter Laca

media:content.media:description: A worker unloads beverages at a cafe in Prague.

item.title: Indonesia Sees ‘Bold’ US Trade Deal, Vows Major Tariff Cuts
item.description: Indonesia is confident it is close to securing a “bold” trade deal with the US that will span critical minerals, energy, defense cooperation and market access ahead of the looming tariff deadline, according to the nation’s chief negotiator.
item.dc:creator: Ben Otto

media:content.media:description: Tanjung Priok Port in Jakarta. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

item.title: German Factory Orders Slump as US Trade Talks Enter Home Stretch
item.description: German factory orders dropped for the first time in four months as businesses at home were wary of committing to large investments before uncertainty over trade with the US is resolved.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow

media:content.media:description: A vehicle paint shop in Wolfsburg, Germany. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: Spain Will Keep Outperforming Euro-Area Peers, Deutsche Bank Says
item.description: Deutsche Bank AG said the Spanish economy will keep outpacing the euro area’s growth after inflation and borrowing costs eased.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Nelson Garcinuno

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians near a Massimo Dutti clothing store in A Coruna, Spain.

item.title: Hungary’s Industry Shrinks More Than Expected on Battery Woes
item.description: Hungary is struggling to turn its industrial sector around, data showed Friday, as weakness in battery production continues to pull back manufacturing.
item.dc:creator: Marton Kasnyik

media:content.media:description: EV battery

item.title: Angola Raises Diesel Price by 33%, Third Increase This Year
item.description: Angola raised the diesel price by 33%, the third increase this year as authorities press ahead with fuel-subsidy cuts that have been encouraged by the International Monetary Fund.
item.dc:creator: Candido Mendes

media:content.media:description: A diesel pump at a gas station. Photographer: Sean Gallup/Getty Images

item.title: ECB Rates in Good Place, Committed to 2% Goal, Lagarde Tells ARD
item.description: The European Central Bank current interest-rate position is appropriate and the institution is fully committed to its 2% inflation target, President Christine Lagarde told ARD.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: South Korea’s Point Man on Trade to Seek Later Tariff Deadline
item.description: South Korea’s top trade official will visit the US this weekend with fresh proposals in a last-minute bid to delay a looming deadline for negotiations before higher tariffs are scheduled to kick in.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Yeo Han-koo in 2022.

item.title: China Plans Nationwide Subsidies to Boost Birthrate
item.description: China is planning to offer cash handouts to families as an incentive for couples to have children, according to people familiar with the matter, as years of population decline threaten the world’s No. 2 economy.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians with a child in Beijing. Photographer: Na Bian/Bloomberg

item.title: US Says GE Aerospace Can Restart Jet Engine Exports to China
item.description: The US has lifted its export ban on American-made jet engine parts and technology to China, according to a person familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Kiel Porter, Danny Lee

media:content.media:description: An attendee checks his mobile phone while standing near a GEnx jet engine, manufactured by General Electric Co., on the opening day of the Farnborough International Airshow (FIA) 2018 in Farnborough, U.K., on Monday, July 16, 2018. The air show, a biannual showcase for the aviation industry, runs until July 22. Photographer: Mary Turner/Bloomberg

item.title: China’s Share of US Imports Falls to 7% as Vietnam Closes in
item.description: Trumps’ tariffs have shifted shipments from China to Southeast Asia
item.dc:creator: Andre Tartar

media:content.media:description: The HMM Aquamarine container ship docked at the Port of Los Angeles in Los Angeles, California, US, on Monday, April 28, 2025. Since the US raised levies on China to 145% in early April, cargo shipments have plummeted, perhaps by as much as 60%, according to one estimate.

item.title: Polish Policymaker Kotecki Says July Cut May Start Easing Cycle
item.description: Poland’s move to cut interest rates this month could be a start of a cycle likely to be continued with two more 25 basis point cuts later this year if data allows, according to policymaker Ludwik Kotecki.
item.dc:creator: Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: A sign for Narodowy Bank Polski at the central bank's headquarters in Warsaw. Photographer: Damian Lemański/Bloomberg

item.title: Labour May Struggle to Impress Voters Even If It Keeps Promises
item.description: Keir Starmer’s government has looked like a circus at times, but on some key targets it is making decent progress.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick

item.title: The Golden Share Makes a Dubious Comeback
item.description: The UK and the US have used special shares to inject the state into the governance of recent takeovers. More could follow. Takeover prices will suffer.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hughes

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump speaks at the US Steel Corporation Irvin Works facility in West Mifflin, Pennsylvania, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. Trump said he would be increasing tariffs on steel to 50% from 25%, saying the move would help protect American steelworkers during a visit to a United States Steel Corp. plant on Friday.

item.title: Early Monsoon Rains in India Raise Hopes of a Bumper Grain Crop
item.description: Early and widespread monsoon rains in India have accelerated the sowing of rice, oilseeds and pulses, boosting the country’s chances of record grain harvest this year, according to the farm ministry’s top bureaucrat.
item.dc:creator: Pratik Parija

media:content.media:description: Farmers sow rice saplings at a paddy field in Baghpat, Uttar Pradesh, on June 29. Photographer: Prakash Singh/Bloomberg

item.title: Goldman Lowers Treasury Yield Forecasts on Rising Fed Cut Bet
item.description: Goldman Sachs Group Inc. has lowered its forecasts for US Treasury yields, pointing to the increased likelihood that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates sooner than previously expected.
item.dc:creator: Masaki Kondo

item.title: Japan’s Ishiba Pushes Back Against Doubts Over US Trade Talks
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba pushed back against the idea there has been little progress in negotiations with the US on a trade deal as a deadline looms for a 24% across-the-board tariff to take force.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami, Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump’s Vietnam Deal Shows China Tariffs Won’t Fall Much Further
item.description: President Donald Trump’s new trade deal with Vietnam sends a clear signal about where US tariffs on Chinese goods might ultimately land, as talks between Washington and Beijing continue following their recent truce.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, Lucille Liu

item.title: Japan’s Households Boost Spending by Most Since Summer 2022
item.description: Japan’s household spending rose the most since the summer of 2022 in a sign that consumer may be getting used to persistent inflation and could support for an economy that’s taking a hit from US tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: A customer holds a bag of government stockpiled rice at a Unidy store in Matsudo, Chiba Prefecture. Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg

item.title: US Deal Leaves Vietnam Grappling With Role in Global Economy
item.description: With the dust far from having settled on this week’s US-Vietnam trade agreement, one thing is clear: companies operating in what’s become one of the most vibrant Asian economies are on notice to move up the value chain.
item.dc:creator: Nguyen Dieu Tu Uyen, Giang Nguyen, Nguyen Xuan Quynh

media:content.media:description: Workers at garment factory in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam.

item.title: Trump Wins Broad Economic Policy Shift as House Passes Tax Bill
item.description: President Donald Trump secured a sweeping shift in US domestic policy as the House passed a $3.4 trillion fiscal package that cuts taxes, curtails spending on safety-net programs and reverses much of Joe Biden’s efforts to move the country toward a clean-energy economy.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Steven T. Dennis, Maeve Sheehey

media:content.media:description: US House Speaker Mike Johnson with House Republicans during an enrollment ceremony following a vote at the US Capitol in Washington, DC. Photographer: Kent Nishimura/Bloomberg

item.title: Greece’s Painful Decade of Rehabilitation Rewards the Believers
item.description: In the summer of 2015, the country stood on the economic precipice. Now, its finances are the envy of Europe — despite the scars.
item.dc:creator: Viktoria Dendrinou, Sotiris Nikas, Paul Tugwell

media:content.media:description: Shoppers on Ermou Street, a busy thoroughfare in Athens, on May 10, 2025.

item.title: Ghana’s Domestic Bond Yields Fall as Inflation Data Spurs Demand
item.description: Ghana’s domestic bond yields extended declines on Thursday after the West African nation reported inflation dropped to the lowest in more than three years.
item.dc:creator: Moses Mozart Dzawu
